awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:   Gentle Atomic Level Chemical Mechanical Smoothening (CMS) of Gallium Nitride Substrates
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop and scale-up an industrially robust and low cost chemical mechanical smoothening
(CMS) process to produce atomically polished gallium nitride (GaN) on silicon substrates for high power and high frequency applications. As GaN is mechanically hard and
chemically inert, traditional surface polishing processes have resulted in significant
surface damage which negatively affects the electrical performance. In contrast, the CMS
process forms a soft layer on GaN surface which can be removed by nanoparticles. In the
Phase II of this project, the company plans to further optimize and scale-up the CMS
process. In conjunction with the compound semiconductor chip manufacturers and
academic partners, the company's plan is to further validate the polishing technology by
fabricating and testing the performance of high electron mobility transistors. The research
team members are internationally recognized experts and are in an excellent position to
execute the research plan and attain the project goals.

The commercialization of the proposed polishing technology is expected to significantly
impact GaN based semiconductor technology used for high frequency, high power
microwave devices in wireless mobile communication and radar defense systems. This
process will accelerate commercialization of GaN on silicon technology by increasing
yield and reducing manufacturing costs.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

 

Sinmat Inc. has developed and commercialized a robust, low-cost chemical mechanical polishing (CMP) process for producing large area, ultra-smooth wide band gap semiconductor wafers that are used in the manufacturing of LEDs, military radars, and communication and power devices. The polishing process developed by Sinmat has significant impact on reducing the cost and time for manufacturing these electronic devices.

The wide band gap semiconductor (Gallium Nitride (GaN) and Silicon Carbide (SiC)) industry encompasses electronic devices used in energy generation, conservation and distribution. The overall addressable market size for these devices is $12 B; this technology has the potential to generate overall energy savings of several billions of dollars. The polishing technology developed by Sinmat (with support from this project), has the potential to save costs worth hundreds of millions of dollars in the manufacturing of wide band gap substrates. The polishing products developed by Sinmat Inc. provide faster and cheaper total polishing solutions for wide band gap semiconductor substrate (Silicon Carbide and Gallium Nitride) manufacturing. When compared to industry standard polishing technologies for SiC and GaN substrates/wafers, Sinmat’s technology offers a more robust, quicker, easier and cost-effective polishing solution for wide band gap semiconductors. The process offers at least 80% more savings in time and costs associated with polishing these ultra-hard and chemically inert materials. Sinmat’s polishing slurries cut down the polishing time from days to less than a couple of hours, and concomitantly delivers ultra-smooth, scratch-free and damage-free flawless surfaces on these wafers. Currently, the CMP technology developed at Sinmat Inc. for wide band gap semiconductors (SiC & GaN) have been used worldwide. In 2008, this CMP product received the R&D 100 Award for being one among the 100 most significant technologies developed in the world during 2008.

Sinmat Inc. received this NSF SBIR Phase II grant in 2007, and in the last six years, the company has transformed itself from a fledgling start-up to a semi-commercial entity. Sinmat has grown from 4 employees in 2007 to 20+ employees in 2012. The company’s revenues have grown five-fold with year over year average growth of 40% in the last 3 years. Back in 2006, Sinmat had zero products and zero commercial sales, and currently it has more than 15 slurry products and multi-million dollar commercial sales. Sinmat has more than 40 customers worldwide some being Global Fortune 500 companies. Sinmat’s customers are spread across the US, Europe and Asia (Japan and Korea). The company is a rare example of a US based and operated entity that makes “products manufactured in the US and exported to Asia and Europe.”

The organic growth helped the company move to a new 10,000 sq. ft. R&D and manufacturing facility last year. Sinmat has been mentioned in the local and national media with even President Obama mentioning Sinmat as one of the emerging companies in the clean technology area. The company won the 2009 Governor’s Innovation Award for the state of Florida and two consecutive R&D 100 awards for CMP technologies in 2008 and 2009. The R&D 100 award is given to the 100 most innovative technologies introduced to the marketplace. The company has its innovative CMP products protected by 20 new patents, applied for or granted in the last six years. It has presented the results of its research at conferences and in journal publications. In addition to public dissemination, Sinmat has also provided invaluable internship opportunities to undergraduate students who have later found jobs in Fortune 500 companies.
